column1: Hey, I'm, uh. I'm really sorry about what happened. I don't um- I mean what you can you do? I mean it's-
column2: Thanks.
column3: When I was seven, my- my grandmother died and I really- I don't know, I mean it was really hard to let go but the important thing is- is that you do let go and your realize that, you know, they- you know, they- this person had fun while they were- while they were here and, uh, you know, you work- you work through it.
column4: You know it's just, I just, you know, I mean it just happened. I just, like- I just keep expecting him to walk in, you know.
column5: Mmhmm. Yeah. Yeah. I mean it's- it's hard. It's hard.
column6: I just- I just thought he would have longer, you know, because I'm- I mean when he found out he was sick, we knew that wasn't good but I just- I just thought that it would take longer, you know?
column7: Yeah.
column8: Well I mean, you know, I mean it was I mean with that kind of condition,
column9: Yeah. I know. I know.
column10: you know, it's inevitable and I mean honestly it's- it's almost like
column11: you know, you don't- you know, how long do you want the person to go through that, you know.
column12: It's sort of- it's almost better off to rest in peace than he is to live in pain.
column13: Yeah, I know. But I'd rather have him here with me, you know. It's just not fair. I mean he- he didn't get to do like anything. I mean he was- M: Yeah.
column14: He was only twenty four and just so many things that we were going to do, you know, and now he won't get to do them and he won't get to be here when I do. You know, like I'll get married some day and he won't be there, like, he won't get to see that.
column15: Yeah.
column16: It just doesn't seem fair.
column17: It's not fair but I mean that's, you know, the course of life is that, you know, you meet people and you lose them. F: Right.
column18: You're okay
column19: Thank you for being here. M: You're welcome.
column20: You know I think- I think we should celebrate because I think that's what he would have wanted.
column21: [LAUGHTER] You're probably right. He probably would be pissed if we were all sitting around being upset about it. He'd want us to have a party.
column22: Yeah.
column23: And to drink in his honor. [LAUGHTER]
column24: That's right. That's right. I mean he would want us to, you know, celebrate the life that he- that he lived and, you know, enjoy the rest of ours as much as we can.
column25: Yeah, I know.

column1: Look sir, I've been waiting for about an hour and my luggage still hasn't come. What's going on?
column2: I'm sorry, Mrs. Rosenkrantz, but uh- I don't know what to tell you.
column3: What do you mean, you don't know what to tell me? I have two luggage that I've been coming--they're coming--from France and I need them here. I'm home now. I need to go start working.
column4: Did you- Did you check with the lost and found?
column5: Where? I don't know. The lost and found. What do you mean, lost and found?
column6: I had my luggage transferred here from Paris to L.A. and now I'm here and I need to be working and I have all my stuff in there.
column7: Maybe it got lost. Did you think about that, mom?
column8: Well, that's what I'm asking you. What--I don't know what happened to it.
column9: Oh, not--we didn't lose it; maybe the airport lost it. Maybe someone stole it.
column10: Wait, sir. You're- You're completely not--what do you mean, stole it? How can they just steal it from an airplane? It was up in the air?
column11: No, I mean, maybe in the little--going around thingy thing where bopper stole it from there.
column12: Okay. All I know is that I am supposed to have my language here right now. Right now. And it's not there. And you're supposed to help me because you work at the airport. So give me my luggage or tell me where the hell it is.
column13: Okay. What can we do is we can get your name and information and if it shows up we can send it to you so-- Wherever you stay
column14: What do you mean, if it shows up? No, I need it now. I have my keys, I have my wallet, I have my money. I have thousands and thousands of dollars worth of stuff in there.
column15: Not to mention I have my work in there.
column16: Well, I'll have you fill out some paperwork and see if you can get started on something.
column17: And what if- what if it is lost? Well, what are you guys going to do for me?
column18: and when you sign your ticket we could replace about fifteen percent of what's in the bag.
column19: Fifteen percent?
column20: Up to a limit of twenty five dollars.
column21: What? There- There's hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of stuff in there.
column22: Whoa, maybe you should uh- have thought of a better way to send it than just in a bag, hmm? Did you think about that?
column23: No, no, no. You don't understand. This is--these are my belongings in the luggage. And I went to Paris.
column24: Sir, why are you laughing at me? This isn't funny.
column25: I think that's kind of stupid, that you put a hundred thousands of dollars in the bag.
column26: Did you lock- Did you lock it even? You probably didn't even lock it.
column27: No, they said I couldn't lock it.
column28: Give me--I'm going to talk to your supervisor. Give me your supervisor. I want to talk to your supervisor right now.
column29: Okay, let me get him.Oh, guess who the supervisor is? It's me.
column31: Well, get- I want the C.E.O. then.

column17: I just want to be honest with you. I don't want you to .

And if for some reason you notice on your statement in a few days that you've been charged and an overdue fee, then you should just call back and we'll have that.

column1: And very much sillier.

column60: You are a vile, ill-tempered, loose living, wicked little beast and I never want to see you again as long as I live.
column61: This is the end. Do you hear me? Finally and forever.
column65: Yes I am. Stop it. Stop it. Let go of me. Oh. You're a cruel fiend. I loathe and I hate you. Marry you again? Never, never, never. I hope you die in torment, you brute beast cad.
column66: Shut up. Shut up. God, I wouldn't marry you again if you came crawling back to me on a bended knee. You are a vile, ill-tempered, mean little wench and I never want to see you again as long as I live.

And if you have to, you know, if you have to question that, you know, don't- don't do it. So we're going to do it.

column18: I thought you wanted to see it.
column19: I did, I do want to see it. I always want to see it, Augie.

column24: We had a bottle of champagne but no glasses and you ask me to dance so we took off our shoes and while we were dancing, you said the most intimate things right in my ears so I could feel them as much as hear them.
column25: And I remember thinking, Finally, finally. I am as happy as I am supposed to be.
column26: Wait a minute, I got it.
column27: Dancing barefoot in the sand, drinking champagne from the bottle.

column31: You want me to go get some champagne?
column35: You want to get married again?

column39: I want something to turn out the way it is suppose to turn out.
column40: What. Welcome to the human race.
column41: No, no I was just like you, I thought it will be all peaches and roses and- and sand in our toes and wind in our hair and the fish will always come. And the bills will always magically pay themselves and we will have three fat rosy kids and we will be, HAHA baby the joke is on us.
column42: This what? What is this? This isn't even anything.
column43: Sure, this is standing. This is waiting. This is fighting.
column44: But this isn't anything like I thought it would be.

column49: No, I know, but. I know I don't make you happy.

column51: Whatever I am doing, I wanted to be with you. I mean you are probably the one who wishes you were with somebody else, somebody who didn't take everything so hard and who knows how to enjoy herself.

column53: Good. So maybe we are on the wrong spot but we are with the right person.

column56: Well, look what we have got here.
column57: No, I am beginning to think that maybe this is the spot after all.

column8: Well.

column16: [BREATHING]

column18: [LAUGHTER]
column19: I don't really have any imagination, that's all I know how to say.
column20: [LAUGHTER]
column21: Am I embarrassing you? Are you - See, I didn't want to do it here with this yard, on this porch. I wanted it to be somewhere new, some place fresh for both of us.
column22: No. No

column24: I almost got married two years ago.
column25: You started to write me.

column35: Like Larry's brother. Do it like you, Chris.

column37: No it's nothing like that. It's-
column38: Yeah. I suppose I have been. But it's going from me.
column39: I don't even know how to start.

column47: Like for instance, there was this one time it had been raining for several days and this kid he just came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks. He just put them in my pocket. That's a little thing, you know, but that's what kind of guys I had.
column48: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other. I mean that, exactly. Just a little more selfish and they would all be here today.
column50: To bring that on to the earth again, you know, is like some kind of monument and I thought I would just make a difference to them.
column51: But then I came home and it was incredible, you know? The whole thing was just kind of this random bus accident. You know, I went back to the rat race again, I went to work.
column52: And I didn't want any of it. I guess that included you.
column53: I just want you to know Annie.
column54: What would I do with a fortune?

column1: You seem kind of down.

column3: It's not fair.

column8: I don't know, I mean, I just don't think...
column9: I mean I've been sending out my resumes and doing everything I can do but nothing is happening. You know, it's like I can't and I can't keep living on loans anymore like this. I'm going to--I mean eventually I'm going to have to pay it back. I'm just kind of freaking out, I don't know.

column17: I guess I just getting really hard to fake, you know.

column21: Yeah.
column22: I come across angry?
column23: No.
column24: What?
column25: Well, you know a little. If you were to listen to--

column38: You have an excuse for everything.

column44: You know, and like I don't think it's that much to ask. I know.
column45: Well, what kind of field are you looking to go into?

column24: I thought you wanted to see it.

column33: Look, do you remember the first time we came here?

column38: You want this to be like the other time right? That's it right?

column46: What? Do you want me to breathe in your ear?
column50: I want things to turn out the way that they're supposed to be.

column53: I was just like you. I thought it was going to be all peaches and roses and everything great and the sand in our toes and the wind in our hair and the fish will always come and the bills will pay themselves and we'd have three big fat rosy kids...
column54: ...and you know? Baby the jokes on us. Because you know what you get? Do you know what you get Carla? You get this.
column55: This what...what's this? This isn't anything. Alright. Sure. Standing on the beach, fighting and waiting.
column58: Cause everything isn't anything like I thought it would be.
column59: This is just this. You know? I mean it's a lot and everything but it isn't somewhere else. Do you know what I'm trying to say?
column60: I'm trying to do the best I can.
column61: I know you are Augie. I know you wanted this evening to be nice.

column66: Augie, whatever I'm doing I'd rather be doing with you.
column67: If anybody wants to be with anybody else it's probably you. Probably somebody who enjoys herself a little more and is not so hard.

column71: Hey, look what we got here.
column73: No I'm beginning to think you might be right.
column74: I think this may be the place for us after all.
column76: Shh. If we're very quiet the fish might come.

column1: Did you talk to him?
column2: He cried hard?
column3: What was he doing out here at that hour?
column4: What do you want to do argue with him?
column5: Why shouldn't he dream of him and walk the nights waiting for him? Do we contradict him? Do we say straight out that we don't have any hope anymore? That we haven't had hope for years now?
column6: You can't say that to him.
column7: We've got to say it to him.
column8: Can you prove it? How can you prove it?
column9: For God sakes, it's been three years. Nobody comes back after three years. It's insane.

column12: I've got an idea, but what's the story?
column13: I'm gonna ask her to marry me.
column14: Well, that's only your business, Chris.
column15: You know it's not only my business.

column18: I'll go ahead with it?
column19: Well, then it isn't just my business--
column20: I'm just saying that--
column21: She's not Larry's girl.
column22: From your father's point of view, he isn't dead. And you've no right to take his girl.
column23: And you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I don't know where to go. See, I don't know. Now what can I do for you?
column24: I don't know why, but, every time I reach out for something that I want, I have to pull back 'cause someone else will suffer. My whole bloody life. Time after time after time.
column25: You're a considerate fellow. There's nothing wrong with that.
column28: Well, how do you know she'll marry you? Maybe she feels the same way your father does.
column29: Well, if she does, then that's the end of it. But from her letters, I think she's forgotten him. I'll find out. And then we'll thrash it out with Dad, right? Mom, don't avoid me.
column30: Trouble is, you don't see enough women.
column32: I just don't see why it has to be Annie.
column34: Well, that's a good answer, but it doesn't answer anything. I mean, you've been away for--at war. It's been five years.
column35: These years when I think of a wife, I think of Annie. What do you want, a diagram?
column36: I don't want a diagram. Umm-- He thinks he's coming back, Chris. You marry that girl and you're pronouncing him dead.
column37: I mean, what's gonna happen to your father? Do you know? I don't.
column38: All right. All right, then, Mom.
column39: I just--give it some more thought.
column40: I've given it three years of thought. I thought that if I waited Dad would forget about Larry and we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

column43: What about the business? What the hell is this?
column44: The business? The business doesn't inspire me.
column46: Yes. I like it an hour a day. If I'm gonna grub for my money all day long, at least in the evening I want it beautiful.
column48: Well, you don't want to think like that.
column49: I know. I know, Mom. Just help me stay here.
column50: All right. Just-- just don't go thinkin' that way, you hear me?
column52: I don't understand you, do I?
column53: No, you don't. I'm a pretty tough guy.

column32: How's the job? Still waiting tables at Denny's?
column35: it's not funny. I just don't know what I'm going to do.
column36: Maybe you could start teaching. I don't know.
column38: Go back to school. You know? Another three more years, get your master's.
column40: Close to thirty. Oof, it's going to be tough.

column1: Why did he invite her here?
column2: Well, maybe he wanted see her.
column3: It's been three and a half years. Why all of a sudden?
column4: Well uh, He grew up next door to the girl, why wouldn't he want to see her?
column5: Don't look at me like that. He didn't tell me anything he told you.
column6: How do you know he's even thinking about it?
column7: Oh so what?
column8: What is going on here, Joe?
column9: Okay, now listen, kids...
column10: The girl is not Larry's. If the girl is Larry's girl she's not his she know she's not.
column11: Listen. Line. You can't read her mind.
column12: And how do you know why she's waited.
column13: Okay, look it's a beautiful day. Why are we arguing?
column14: Nobody in this house dares take away her faith Joe. Her- strangers might but not her father, not her brother.
column15: What do you want me to do? What do you want?
column16: I want you to---act like he is coming back. Don't think I haven't noticed you, both of you since Chris invited her here. I won't stand for any nonsense.
column17: Kate...
column18: [BREATHING]
column19: Oh, laugh at me, laugh all you like but why does this happen to very night she comes back? She goes to sleep in his room and his memorial breaks in pieces. Look at it, Joe look.
column20: All right, calm yourself.
column21: Believe with me Joe, you got to believe. Only last week a boy came back missing longer then Larry you read it yourself.
column22: Okay, calm yourself. Alright.
column23: calm yourself.
column24: You above all have got to believe. Just don't stop believing.
column25: What does that mean? Me above all? What does that mean?
column27: What the hell do you want from me, Kate?

column1: The only one I know still love his parents.
column2: Yeah, that kind of went out of style didn't it?
column3: Oh it's not bad thing it's good thing.
column4: You're not sorry you came?
column5: Not sorry, no. I can't stay here.
column6: Why not?
column7: For one thing your mother as much as told me to go.
column8: [BREATHING] And then you've been kind of...
column9: What?
column10: You've been kind of embarrassed ever since I got here.
column11: You did?
column12: From her point of view why else would I come?
column13: Yeah--
column14: Ann, I love you. I love you. F:[LAUGHTER]
column15: I almost got married two years ago.
column16: Why didn't you?
column17: Everyday since.
column18: why didn't you let me know?
column19: Because I was waiting for you, Chris. Till then you never wrote me and then when you did, well, you sure can be ambiguous you know.
column20: I kissed you. I kissed Annie.
column21: I'll never forgive you for waiting so long. All I did was sit around and wonder if I was crazy for thinking about you.
column22: I kissed you.
column23: Chris, what's the matter?
column24: Do you want to go somewhere? Let's go.
column25: No, what is it? Is your mother?
column26: No, no, it's nothing like that.
column27: I don't know it's--it's complicated. But it's going from me now. F: You got to...
column29: I don't know. F: But what if...
column30: It's kind of all mixed up with all these other things.
column32: you know over seas I was in command of the company?
column38: Takes awhile to toss something like that off. I mean they weren't just men, you know.
column39: For instance, there was this one time when this kid--it had been raining for like several days and he gave me his last pair of dry socks.
column40: He just put it in my pocket that's the kind of guys I had.
column41: They didn't die they killed themselves for each other and I mean that exactly, you know a little more selfish and they'll all be here today...
column42: And I had this idea as I was watching them go down like everything was being destroyed, you know. But I felt like this one new thing was being made, you know it's kind of like this. This monument...
column43: You know, that they were bringing something on to this earth, a kind of sacrifice you know.
column44: I thought I would change everything you know, and I got back here and it was- it was like nothing had changed at all...
column45: You know. I went to work with dad and I started that whole rat race again...
column46: And no one had changed it was just like sort of random bus accident to them.
column47: Driving my new car and I felt guilty you know opening my bank book seeing a new refrigerator.
column48: 'Cause you can take those things out of a war. But you have to realize that those things came out of the love that a man can have for another man...
column49: And if you can't see that then it's just loot and there's blood all over it.
column50: I felt ashamed and I didn't want any part of it. I guess I included you too.
column51: Do you still feel that way?
column52: I want you to know Annie.
column53: I'm going to make a fortune for you.
column54: What would I do with a fortune?
